title: Accreditation IT Support Specialist
summary:
This role felt like working in a mission-critical war room — minus the explosions. As part of the accreditation team for the G7 Summit, I was the go-to person whenever a printer stopped printing, a laptop refused to behave, or an ODBC connection gave up. And yes, people called out “Joseph!” a lot.

Under heavy pressure and tight deadlines, I managed badge printing systems (AlphaCard, Entrust, Zebra), maintained smooth data connections, and kept everything running — all with a smile. It was intense, but deeply rewarding. I learned how to thrive in high-stakes environments and still be the calm in the storm.

title: Full Stack Developer
summary:
Working in a small, tight-knit remote team, I handled bug fixes, feature development, and utility billing improvements for a campground reservation system. Thanks to my familiarity with Angular, Spring Boot, and JHipster, I ramped up quickly and became productive from day one.

We communicated constantly, solved problems fast, and shipped often. Although the company was acquired by Campspot during my time there, I stepped away to pursue the G7 opportunity — but I truly enjoyed the rhythm of daily collaboration and building something useful for real users.

title: Full Stack Developer
summary:
This was a short-term contract that came through a personal connection. The codebase? Over 10 years old and built with Spring MVC — let’s just say it had character.

Despite the learning curve, I dove in and delivered a full “Student Notes” module that helped teachers track and manage academic comments. It gave me a taste of legacy system challenges, and a reminder that not all tech is shiny — but all of it matters.

title: Full Stack Developer
summary:
This was my longest and most formative role. I started with Groovy and Grails, working alongside TIBCO BusinessWorks to move data around financial systems — and then, as the company evolved, so did I.

I transitioned into Angular and Spring Boot microservices (back when Angular 2 was still fresh), and helped build risk management tools that improved fraud detection and case handling.

The team? Amazing. The vibe? Productive and supportive.
If the Calgary office hadn’t closed, I might still be there today.

title: Software Developer
summary:
My first Canadian tech job after graduating from SAIT — and it felt like a fast-paced startup adventure.

Userful was building a visualization platform that let multiple users interact with various OS environments and control massive video walls like one giant monitor. I worked on legacy PHP code, enhanced GWT-based tools, and contributed to a controller app that managed the wall system.

It was fascinating tech and a great first step into the Canadian tech industry — though when Paysafe called, I answered.

title: System Application Developer
summary:
Back in Korea, this was my first job out of university — deep in the world of C and Unix networking. I wrote daemon processes to handle transaction parsing, built backend systems that communicated with vendors, and kept servers stable using shell scripts and Crontab.

It was low-level, high-responsibility work, and I learned a lot about performance, networking, and how systems really talk to each other. I even dipped my toes into kernel studies back then — though I’ll admit, the details are fuzzy now.
